articles.headline: 6 European Nations Get Downgrades
articles.snippet: Moody’s also became the first ratings agency to switch Britain’s outlook to negative, citing “the increased uncertainty regarding the pace of fiscal consolidation.”
articles.abstract: Moody’s also became the first ratings agency to switch Britain’s outlook to negative, citing “the increased uncertainty regarding the pace of fiscal consolidation.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Moody’s Investors Service cut the debt ratings on Monday of six European countries, including Italy, Spain and Portugal, and became the first big ratings agency to switch Britain’s outlook to negative.

articles.headline: House Republicans Yield on Extending Payroll Tax Cut
articles.snippet: A surprise announcement called for separating a proposed extension from negotiations over jobless benefits and Medicare reimbursements.
articles.abstract: A surprise announcement called for separating a proposed extension from negotiations over jobless benefits and Medicare reimbursements.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans backed down on Monday from a demand that a payroll tax rollback be paid for with reductions in other programs, clearing the way for an extension of the tax cut for 160 million Americans through 2012.

articles.headline: Small-Cap Stocks Surge Ahead of the Big Names
articles.snippet: In a Wall Street universe full of marquee stocks, lesser known entities are the stars of the rally so far this year.
articles.abstract: In a Wall Street universe full of marquee stocks, lesser known entities are the stars of the rally so far this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a Wall Street universe populated by marquee name stocks, the lesser known entities are the stars of the rally so far this year.

articles.headline: For California, Attorney General Insisted on Better Terms in Foreclosure Deal
articles.snippet: Kamala D. Harris took a hard line in negotiations with banks, but faced increasing pressure from the White House to reach a deal.
articles.abstract: Kamala D. Harris took a hard line in negotiations with banks, but faced increasing pressure from the White House to reach a deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Kamala D. Harris, the attorney general of California, could have derailed a nationwide settlement with big banks over home foreclosure abuses when she walked out of talks last September.

articles.headline: Apple Asks Outside Group to Inspect Factories
articles.snippet: Apple said the Fair Labor Association had begun auditing working conditions at Chinese factories where Apple products are made. The first inspections involved a Shenzhen factory known as Foxconn City.
articles.abstract: Apple said the Fair Labor Association had begun auditing working conditions at Chinese factories where Apple products are made. The first inspections involved a Shenzhen factory known as Foxconn City.
articles.lead_paragraph: 9:10 p.m. | Updated to add more details throughout.
articles.byline: By Charles Duhigg and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Critics Question Record of Monitor Selected by Apple
articles.snippet: The Fair Labor Association, the firm that Apple has hired to examine worker conditions at the plants of its suppliers, has been criticized by labor groups as ineffective.
articles.abstract: The Fair Labor Association, the firm that Apple has hired to examine worker conditions at the plants of its suppliers, has been criticized by labor groups as ineffective.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple’s announcement on Monday that an outside monitoring group, the Fair Labor Association, has begun inspecting its suppliers’ factories in China rekindled a debate over how effective the group has been in eliminating labor abuses.

articles.headline: Model Struts Path to Stardom Not on Runway, but on YouTube
articles.snippet: Kate Upton has arrived on the fashion scene as a largely self-created phenomenon and will be the latest cover girl for Sports Illustrated’s annual swimsuit issue.
articles.abstract: Kate Upton has arrived on the fashion scene as a largely self-created phenomenon and will be the latest cover girl for Sports Illustrated’s annual swimsuit issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was a time, not long ago, when the surest path to modeling stardom was down the runway of a top designer’s show, when it would have been unthinkable to find among the industry’s top ranks a swimsuit girl whose main claims to fame were ad campaigns for Guess jeans and Beach Bunny Swimwear.

articles.headline: California Set to Send Many New Faces to Washington
articles.snippet: Between redistricting and a growing number of retirements, the face of California’s 53-member Congressional delegation is set to get younger.
articles.abstract: Between redistricting and a growing number of retirements, the face of California’s 53-member Congressional delegation is set to get younger.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — California’s Congressional delegation, the largest and most influential in the nation, is undergoing a major upheaval, the result of reapportionment and retirements, threatening the state’s influence in Washington next year and forcing members to scramble to withstand what is emerging as a generational wave.

articles.headline: With Edge, U.S. Greets China’s Heir Apparent
articles.snippet: China’s vice president, Xi Jinping, was met with blunt criticism from Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who declared that the United States and China could cooperate “only if the game is fair.”
articles.abstract: China’s vice president, Xi Jinping, was met with blunt criticism from Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who declared that the United States and China could cooperate “only if the game is fair.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — China’s vice president and likely future leader, Xi Jinping, embarked on a get-to-know-you tour of the United States on Tuesday, with a day of meetings from the White House to the Pentagon. But he was met with blunt criticism from his host, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who declared that the United States and China could cooperate “only if the game is fair.”
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Edward Wong
